title: The Potentially High Cost of Being Friends With the Boss
text:
Friends with the boss? It turns out that might cost you.

Studies have shown that managers typically give preferential treatment to those who are close to them or share something in common, like a group identity.

But now researchers say there’s a situation where it’s bad to be the boss’s friend. When managers are handing out bonuses—and when employees will know who gets the rewards—the bosses want to avoid the appearance of bias. So, they often pass over their pals and favor other workers.

“People want to be fair, and they also want to help out their friends,” says researcher Alex Shaw, an assistant professor of psychology at the University of Chicago. “But the role of a manager is to be impartial, rewarding workers based on their efforts, and these two tendencies can conflict in the office when you’re supposed to avoid favoritism.”

Virtual connections

In a recent study, published in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, Dr. Shaw and a team of researchers created eight virtual office situations where 1,200 online participants surveyed through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, a platform often employed by psychologists, had to decide how to award a bonus or another benefit.

In these scenarios, participants were asked to imagine being a boss who was tasked with deciding how to assign a bonus to one of two people—a friend or another employee. The bosses could either reward the person based on merit or flip a coin and let fate decide. In some cases they were told the decision would be public, and in other cases private.

The result? Friends tended to suffer when the decisions were made public. In those cases, bosses rewarded the deserving employee 25% less when that person was their friend. In private, though, bosses tended to reward the slightly more deserving employee at equally high rates, whether the employee was a friend or not.

However, there was one case where public decisions did favor friends—when company resources weren’t at stake. “We found that when bosses are distributing their own resources, like their own personal tickets to ‘Hamilton,’ they do show preference to their friends,” says Dr. Shaw.

Why? The survey-takers believed other employees would approve of that decision because “people do not generally think it is inappropriate to give more to friends in the interpersonal domain,” says Dr. Shaw, under which something like offering one’s own extra theater tickets falls.

Playing fair

While Dr. Shaw and his team did not study the broader implications of his findings, they do speculate in the paper that reverse bias could apply to many situations. This could include times when academics review friends’ papers, when politicians tackle political issues involving friends, even when coaches are working with their friends’—or their own—children.

“We also speculate that this may apply to group membership as well,” Dr. Shaw says. “One could imagine a reporter with liberal politics being worried about appearing biased, so he might be harder on a liberal than a conservative to appear unbiased.”

There are a few ways bosses can avoid the bias fears regarding friends, he says. “If you’re in a position where you can let someone else decide whom to reward, you should recuse yourself,” Dr. Shaw says, adding, “It can be hard to trust your own judgment in situations where you have conflicting biases.”

Another strategy is to ask other people’s opinions. Since a public decision to reward a friend might appear partial, as long as many other people agree that this person is deserving, the idea that the leader is practicing favoritism might be diminished.

Last, says Dr. Shaw, if the criteria for making the bonus are explicit, that could help colleagues recognize that the allocation of bonuses is fair. “Make the rules really clear, like saying that the person who produces the most units will get a bonus,” he says. “That could be useful to mitigate the appearance of favoritism.”

Ms Mitchell is a writer in Chicago. She can be reached at reports@wsj.com.
description: When the office knows who’s getting a bonus, managers favor other employees to avoid the appearance of bias.
